abstract: Suicide of former Marine Corporal Tyler Schlagel in Longmont, Colo, is 14th in his military unit since they returned from Afghanistan tour in 2008, and many other members have made attempts on their lives; rate of suicide for Second Batallion, unit of 1,200 Marines, is almost four times higher than for all young male veterans; veterans fall between cracks of military's authority once they leave active duty and a Veteran's Dept whose responsibilities start only if veterans come in seeking benefits or medical care, which many do not.
lead_paragraph: The suicide rate in one Marine regiment is 14 times as high as that for all Americans, but the government’s ability to monitor and treat veterans is halting and incomplete.

headline.main: Suicide Claims 14th Marine From a Unit Battered by Loss
headline.print_headline: Another Suicide in a Marine Unit Battered by Loss

snippet: The suicide rate in one Marine regiment is 14 times as high as that for all Americans, but the government’s ability to monitor and treat veterans is halting and incomplete.
